Subject:
 RE: DNS Whitelist Update During Deployment
 
Hi Guanglin,
 
Thanks for the clarification. 
I must admit that it s sound very strange to me. DNS Whitelisting is not a new service. We are offering this since years. It seems that we never come to clarify this point. 
CCCS did manage it for Sealink + since the introduction of DNS Whitelisting for Back up configuration. 
From FE feedback, this configuration was done during deployment by FE when there was IT policy, SOW or in IOF.
It seems that nobody knows who did this in other situations… 
 
So, we need to define which department should do it now and in the future during deployment or change projects.
 
My opinion:
As soon as it s managed by a Project Manager, it should be part of the list of tasks to deploy/change via ticket to CCCS. 
CCCS knows how to do it. 
Today, CCCS receive ticket to unbar the box, receive ticket to apply a price matrix. It could be another one to apply a DNS Whitelist with the list of site to whitelist.
 
@VESTBY, Lars
, 
@LIPKA, Marek
,
Does it make sense for you? Do you have any other suggestions?
I can draft a process for this. Let me know.
 
Kind regards,
 
Luc Feron
Director Competence Centers 
Marlink SAS 
CECS Aussaguel
31450 Issus – France
M +33 (0)6 71 04 65 04
E  
luc.feron@marlink.com

Subject:
 DNS Whitelist Update During Deployment
 
Hi Gents,
 
The below two tickets were created by change team, requesting for DNS whitelist updates, and there are confusions on which team should be responsible for such.
 
1808597 Spirit of Sydney 
1784092 Spirit of Singapore 
 
In short, teams have different opinions:
Change team: it’s under CCCS as in attached
CCCS team: “CCCS is doing DNS white list setting only for Sealink+ Backup devices … we don't touch DNS settings on the XChange boxes”
CSE: “This is FE job”
 
RCS will complete 1808597 this time, just since it’s been pending for too long. But we need a clear guideline for future reference.
 
Thanks.
BR
Guanglin

Subject:
 RE: NEW MERITS NT OP features
 
Hi guys,
 
Was below email shared with all RCS teams?
I came across few tickets were RCS points out to higher RX BBP Error Ratio, but Newtec modem software version was older than 4.7.2.1 in which case this graph is irrelevant.
 
Please share / send reminder regarding this as it seems to be confusing some people.
 
Thank you and have a good day.
Best Regards,
Adam Sevecek
 
From:
 ZAGAJEC, Lukas <
Lukas.Zagajec@marlink.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, January 17, 2025 10:49 AM
To:
 Team MNOC Bratislava <
TeamMNOCBratislava@marlink.com
>; NAMBIARMALIL JOHN, Joel <
Joel.NambiarmalilJohn@marlink.com
>
Cc:
 Team RCS MGMT <
Team.RCS_MGMT@marlink.com
>; Team RCS Athens <
team.rcsathens@marlink.com
>; THORESEN, Linn - Andrea <
linn-andrea.thoresen@marlink.com
>; HOLTRIN, Erik <
erik.holtrin@marlink.com
>
Subject:
 NEW MERITS NT OP features
 
Hi guys,
 
Few things implemented on NT OP page -> STATUS tab:
RX BBP Error Ratio Stats:
This feature is available 
ONLY for modems with firmware release 4.7.2.1 and newer
!
With older versions -> it will show a lot of errors, but all are false, like example below:
So it's important to check currently running modem software version.
You can trust only if modem is running 4.7.2.1 (and higher, in the future).
 
 
 
RX Link Margin:
Definition: 
Difference between the measured EsN0 and the required EsN0 to support the current MODCOD
 
 
 
Latency from HUB:
We are now able to measure two main latencies:
Latency from HUB -> description is missing for now (will be added), but it's "Latency and packet loss measured from used teleport to remote"
Latency from Eik-> Latency and packet loss measured from Eik teleport to remote
So as you can see, latency for below example from the teleport is 600 ms, but from Eik -> it's hitting almost 1000 ms:
 
IF you will have some questions, please feel free to ask.
 
BR,
Lukas

Ticket: #1772280
Installation: Safeen Prism- KU - Intellian V100
Customer: GFS SHIP MANAGEMENT FZE
Action: Update
Registered: {ts '2025-06-12 15:23:05'} UTC
Category: Incident
Reported by: Captain
Description: VSAT is offline, no internet onboard
State: - New ticket created - by Thales Trabbold on 24 Apr 2025
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Captain,
We sincerely apologize, as it appears there was a miscommunication earlier.
My colleague asked earlier to restart the antenna by turning antenna breaker off, can you please kindly verify if this has been done and if so, was the switch turned back on ?
Additionally, could you advise whether the antenna performed the initialization process following the restart?
  
We kindly request that you measure the voltage on the RX ACU output (Rx path), and check all related connectors for any signs of damage or irregularities along the path.
Awaiting your kind reply.
 
Best regards,
Boris Benyik

Forti manager
Forti analyzer
 
 
Forti manager
- device manager
                - device groups: up error: means UTM is synced and connected to forti manager on shore. Otherwise, it means UTM is not connected, but it's still running on board; "config status": this means the config matches, not whether it's online; "policy package" : normally 1 customer 1 package
 
To check on the UTM
 
variable mapping: to check if the IPs match, especially for new deployments. Blank = take the default value
 
 
Policy & Objects
                - Policy packages (to view the submenu, need to go to tools, to turn it on)
                
                - firewall virtual: rules 1-10 are marlink default, can't be changed; LAN 1 is physical port, and vXC1 is virtual port; "security profiles" does additional checks; No. 9 is configure on cyberguard portal
                questions: no need 2 rules? just outgoing/incoming

 Sunday, May 11, 2025 8:33 AM

Subject:
 SLA Dashboards
 
Hi Team,
Below are the two dashboards. Please keep an eye on them to monitor the report accuracy.
TTO  
Dashboard link
TTU  
Dashboard link
All timestamps are in UTC.
TTO:
This updates at 12 AM every day, and consists of two parts:
A table listing all RCS tickets that violated TTO in the past 24 hours
Default TTO is 120 mins,  except 60 mins on CMA and 30 mins on Boskalis. 
Hourly average TTO trend across the last 24 hours
 
This dashboard only monitors tickets created by RCS.
 
Data on 9
th
 May, captured yesterday:
 
Note:
Time reference is based on the email received timestamp (InDateTime)
Timestamps are rounded down to the hour (e.g., 01:59 AM is grouped under 1 AM). This setting can be adjusted later if needed.
Full ticket list can be found on 
Detailed ticket table
, for cross checking.
 
 
TTU 
This report captures TTU every 4 hrs, 6 times a day, and it only checks on “in progress” & unassigned RCS tickets.
Column charts show the longest delay since 
the last ticket action
. 
E.g., at 12 AM UTC 10
th
 May, ticket 1782530 had the longest delay, of 16.2 hrs
Similarly, 4 hrs later, at 4 AM, out of all RCS tickets, ticket 1760491 had the longest delay, of 4.3 hrs 
The 3 delayed tickets are displayed underneath the chart, for cross checking
This dashboard is a collection of 6 induvial reports, each refreshing at different hours, as indicated by “Snapshothour”. 
 E.g., the 3
st
 one, Snapshot 8 means that report updates at 8 AM daily. So, if I check that at 4AM here, then I’m still seeing yesterday’s data, so 0.9 was what we left with 
yesterday
. But if Rasto checks that at 10AM, then that report should have already updated, so it will show what they start with 
today
 
This is the same logic that Merits dashboard uses. E.g., at 12 AM, 1782530 was on the top of our dashboard:
 
Limitations:  
Due to some licensing constraints, TTU dashboard only records the data for last 24 hrs, and we can’t backtrace further or adjust the time frame easily. 
It’s known that above logic may underestimate TTU, since it only checks the last action, not the last customer incoming email. I have made another dashboard based on ticket Changelog  
Dashboard link
, which calculates how long the ticket has been in “In Progress” status, but for now, I suggest use the one above for consistency , as it aligns with how Merits works
 
@TSOTRAS, Antonios
 Your teams are not yet included in these dashboards, as they are under a different Merits Resource ID. If helpful, I can add your team in, or you can refer to my Wednesday email and set up your own version. I’m sure you’ll enjoy that.
Thanks.
BR
Guanglin

Hello Guanglin, hello Michal,
 
Let me first apologise for the late answer.
 
The rule that prevails is: we will assist customers with their MSS terminal provided they have the corresponding airtime 
or
 the purchased/leased the hardware with Marlink.
 
Down to the question related to the terminal ownership i.e. purchased from Marlink or leased from Marlink or purchased via a different provider, as long the airtime is with Marlink we will assist them in the process:
In case of a lease: we will proceed throughout until the hardware is swapped
In case of customer purchase (from Marlink), if covered with warranty we will proceed throughout, if beyond warranty will help until the identification (with manufacturer’s confirmation) of the part to be purchased and handover to the sales responsible
In case of customer purchase (from a different provider), we will help until identification (with manufacturer’s confirmation) of the part to be replaced and handover to the customer
 
When it comes to checking the terminal ownership, we rely on the details in Merits and in the vessel’s SPO. When it comes to the checking the terminal’s warranty, the MNOC was trained and knows how to check it.
 
Now, regarding the very tickets quoted in the email from Guanglin, these look to be exceptions where the process was not followed from the beginning or where there has been unusual things happening. completion:
Hi,
 
FYI. This is about how to access AP on their factory IP. This becomes possible with the new VLAN feature on Xchange LAN. I asked Thales as I saw it in 
1807331 - CMA CGM Pegasus
. 
 
BR
Guanglin
 
From:
 TRABBOLD, Thales <Thales.Trabbold@marlink.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, June 12, 2025 8:32 PM
To:
 SI, Guanglin <Guanglin.Si@marlink.com>
Subject:
 ENC: How to configured factory default D-Link Wi-Fi APs
 
Hi Guanglin,
 
Fowarding to you. I fowarded to Houston RCS, but I'll ask to foward to all RCS.
 
De:
 TRABBOLD, Thales <
Thales.Trabbold@marlink.com
>
Enviado:
 quarta-feira, 11 de junho de 2025 17:45
Para:
 Team RCS Houston <
Team.RCSHouston@marlink.com
>
Assunto:
 How to configured factory default D-Link Wi-Fi APs
 
Hello team,
 
I am sharing a procedure that can help us on a lot of tickets. I am seeing it specially on CMA CGM Tickets - see 
1807331 - CMA CGM Pegasus
 and 
1796621 - CMA CGM Tigris
 as examples.
 
See details of the issue:
Customer usually reaches us complaining about the Wi-Fi network (low performance, frequent disconnections and others).
Starting the troubleshoot, we check that there is some Wi-Fi APs that cannot be reached on the network. We ask customer to restart, check MACs, and more...
 
This issue is caused because the Wi-Fi APs returned to the factory default IP (192.168.0.50) or even returned to all factory settings after a power cycle. Since vessel have at least three APs, they started to conflict between them because of the equal IP, leading to disconnections and other issues.
 
See below the procedure to access the Wi-Fi APs over their factory IP and restore their access over the LAN2 configured network (note that this procedure will lead to total disconnection of the Wi-Fi network on the vessel over the time spent on the configurations - around 1h, depending on the connection speed).
 
Access the vessel's  XChange Box URA. Access the XChange Web page and go to 
Box Settings -> Network -> LAN/WAN
.
Create a new temporary LAN calles APs, like below:
Now, assign this LAN to the LAN2 interface and restart the XChange Box.
NOTE¹
 - 
DO NOT
 make this configuration over the Start Wizard, since it can change the decides priorities.
NOTE²
 - You can do this kind of configuration on XChange v5.4.0 and v5.5.0 too, but you need to save all LAN2 configurations before the change, since the function of create several separated LANs only arrived on v5.6.0.
 
After the restart, access the XChange Box again. Go to the internet browser and access the AP web page over the IP 192.168.0.50:
The User Name is always 
admin
. password can be 
stddzWIFI 
or 
stddzWIFI2020 
(most actual one) or leave password blank.
 
At the left menu, go to 
Basic Setting -> LAN
. Select Static IP and set an IP on the LAN2 that is free (In this case, 10.0.2.111) and click save. 
NOTE 
-
 DO NOT
 set DHCP. If you set DCHP now, it will try to get an IP and it will not find and return to the factory IP.
 
IMPORTANT!!!
 - After that, go to 
Configuration 
and click 
Save and Activate
. The AP will restart.
If you don't click on Save and Activate, the AP will not save the configuration to the flash memory and after a power cycle, these setting will be lost.
 
If there is more then one AP with the factory default IP, reload the page with 192.168.0.50 and you will access the next one. Repeat the steps 4, 5 and 6 and set another fixed IP (10.0.2.112, for example) to this new AP. Keep doing that until you do not find any APs on this network anymore. You can let a command prompt window with the command "ping 192.168.0.50 -t" running to see if you can still find any AP on the network.
 
After you set them, return to the XChange Web Page and return the LAN2 to the LAN2 interface
After that, delete the AP LAN previously created:
Restart the XChange again.
 
After the restart, the APs will be accessible correctly now. Access them over the new IP address set, change the password to stddzWIFI2020 and configured just as the commissioning guide 
"20200323 XChange WiFi configuration manual v12.5.pdf"
.
Do not forget to click 
Save and Activate
 at the end of the configuration!!!
 
With these steps, you will standardize the Wi-FI APs configuration at the vessel and eliminate the IP conflict between them. 
 
If you have any doubts regarding this procedure, let me know 
🙂
 
-----------------------------------------------------
Best Regards
Thales Trabbold
RCS Support Engineer - Rio de Janeiro

That said, I fully understand that MNOC generally has stronger technical expertise and is more focused on troubleshooting. It’s understandable if CCTS prefers MNOC to review UTM tickets first. Subject:

Hi Servicedesk
Great news, Marlink is now officially providing PRA managed services for Boskalis via Bitsiel’s BeyondTrust platform!
 
Since we consider remaining part of June a “hyper care” phase, we agreed with Boskalis to share a joint issue list: 
 Marlink PRA MSP - Hyper care Issue list.xlsx
. File should be accessible and editable for all Marlink users. 
Note! A few named Bitsiel and Boskalis users have access to this file.
 
As you can see, customer has started adding observations to this list. According to Bitsiel, the two items added as of writing this email can be addressed using the Support scripts provided as part of the training. I added the two observations below for your convenience:
#
Description
1
Downloading a file goes only to the download folder. User want to choose where to download to on their machine.
2
User was able to create new jump items
 
Considering no “Owner” is explicitly added to the items in issue list, I assume Boskalis expects Marlink to resolve even if during hyper care phase, Boskalis still has two named users with temporary admin access to the BeyondTrust portal, for enabling quick resolution of minor things. I’ve asked them to fill “Owner” going forward.
 
Also, Bitsiel has looked at the items in the list and is expecting Marlink Servicedesk to contact them for joint resolution, since this is a first for Marlink.
 
I’ll remind Boskalis to include Marlink Servicedesk in any new observations/incidents going forward, to build the right habit at the start of the operational phase.
 
Please reach out if anything unclear.
 
Vennlig hilsen / Kind regards,
Thomas

Voice@marlink result is released. Overall, our score is stable. We will review that next Wednesday
Company is putting more resources on the ABC strategy, and more sales have been hired for IT products

BR

From:
 ARGANESE, Franck <Franck.Arganese@marlink.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, May 14, 2025 12:51 AM
To:
 HORVATH, Michal <michal.horvath@marlink.com>; SI, Guanglin <Guanglin.Si@marlink.com>
Cc:
 Team RCS MGMT <Team.RCS_MGMT@marlink.com>
Subject:
 RE: MSS Terminal Ownership
 
Hello Guanglin, hello Michal,
 
Let me first apologise for the late answer.
 
The rule that prevails is: we will assist customers with their MSS terminal provided they have the corresponding airtime 
or
 the purchased/leased the hardware with Marlink.
 
Down to the question related to the terminal ownership i.e. purchased from Marlink or leased from Marlink or purchased via a different provider, as long the airtime is with Marlink we will assist them in the process:
In case of a lease: we will proceed throughout until the hardware is swapped
In case of customer purchase (from Marlink), if covered with warranty we will proceed throughout, if beyond warranty will help until the identification (with manufacturer’s confirmation) of the part to be purchased and handover to the sales responsible
In case of customer purchase (from a different provider), we will help until identification (with manufacturer’s confirmation) of the part to be replaced and handover to the customer
 
When it comes to checking the terminal ownership, we rely on the details in Merits and in the vessel’s SPO. When it comes to the checking the terminal’s warranty, the MNOC was trained and knows how to check it.
 
Now, regarding the very tickets quoted in the email from Guanglin, these look to be exceptions where the process was not followed from the beginning or where there has been unusual things happening. These can’t be used as examples. I’ll let you review them in detail if you like. I actually wanted to do but I failed to have enough time to do it thoroughly.
 
Kind regards
Franck Arganese
Technical Support Manager
Competence Centre 
·
 Technical Support

E

​​
www.marlink.com

Context: ...
completion:

BR
Guanglin
 
From:
 TRABBOLD, Thales <Thales.Trabbold@marlink.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, June 12, 2025 8:32 PM
To:
 SI, Guanglin <Guanglin.Si@marlink.com>
Subject:
 ENC: How to configured factory default D-Link Wi-Fi APs
 
Hi Guanglin,
 
Fowarding to you. I fowarded to Houston RCS, but I'll ask to foward to all RCS.
 
De:
 TRABBOLD, Thales <
Thales.Trabbold@marlink.com
>
Enviado:
 quarta-feira, 11 de junho de 2025 17:45
Para:
 Team RCS Houston <
Team.RCSHouston@marlink.com
>
Assunto:
 How to configured factory default D-Link Wi-Fi APs
 
Hello team,
 
I am sharing a procedure that can help us on a lot of tickets. I am seeing it specially on CMA CGM Tickets - see 
1807331 - CMA CGM Pegasus
 and 
1796621 - CMA CGM Tigris
 as examples.
 
See details of the issue:
Customer usually reaches us complaining about the Wi-Fi network (low performance, frequent disconnections and others).
Starting the troubleshoot, we check that there is some Wi-Fi APs that cannot be reached on the network. We ask customer to restart, check MACs, and more...
 
This issue is caused because the Wi-Fi APs returned to the factory default IP (192.168.0.50) or even returned to all factory settings after a power cycle. Since vessel have at least three APs, they started to conflict between them because of the equal IP, leading to disconnections and other issues.
 
See below the procedure to access the Wi-Fi APs over their factory IP and restore their access over the LAN2 configured network (note that this procedure will lead to total disconnection of the Wi-Fi network on the vessel over the time spent on the configurations - around 1h, depending on the connection speed).
 
Access the vessel's  XChange Box URA. Access the XChange Web page and go to 
Box Settings -> Network -> LAN/WAN
.
Create a new temporary LAN calles APs, like below:
Now, assign this LAN to the LAN2 interface and restart the XChange Box.
NOTE¹
 - 
DO NOT
 make this configuration over the Start Wizard, since it can change the decides priorities.
NOTE²
 - You can do this kind of configuration on XChange v5.4.0 and v5.5.0 too, but you need to save all LAN2 configurations before the change, since the function of create several separated LANs only arrived on v5.6.0.
 
After the restart, access the XChange Box again. Go to the internet browser and access the AP web page over the IP 192.168.0.50:
The User Name is always 
admin
. password can be 
stddzWIFI 
or 
stddzWIFI2020 
(most actual one) or leave password blank.
 
At the left menu, go to 
Basic Setting -> LAN
. Select Static IP and set an IP on the LAN2 that is free (In this case, 10.0.2.111) and click save. 
NOTE 
-
 DO NOT
 set DHCP. If you set DCHP now, it will try to get an IP and it will not find and return to the factory IP.
 
IMPORTANT!!!
 - After that, go to 
Configuration 
and click 
Save and Activate
. The AP will restart.
If you don't click on Save and Activate, the AP will not save the configuration to the flash memory and after a power cycle, these setting will be lost.
 
If there is more then one AP with the factory default IP, reload the page with 192.168.0.50 and you will access the next one. Repeat the steps 4, 5 and 6 and set another fixed IP (10.0.2.112, for example) to this new AP. Keep doing that until you do not find any APs on this network anymore. You can let a command prompt window with the command "ping 192.168.0.50 -t" running to see if you can still find any AP on the network.
 
After you set them, return to the XChange Web Page and return the LAN2 to the LAN2 interface
After that, delete the AP LAN previously created:
Restart the XChange again.
 
After the restart, the APs will be accessible correctly now. Access them over the new IP address set, change the password to stddzWIFI2020 and configured just as the commissioning guide 
"20200323 XChange WiFi configuration manual v12.5.pdf"
.
Do not forget to click 
Save and Activate
 at the end of the configuration!!!
 
With these steps, you will standardize the Wi-FI APs configuration at the vessel and eliminate the IP conflict between them. 
 
If you have any doubts regarding this procedure, let me know 
🙂
 
-----------------------------------------------------
Best Regards
Thales Trabbold
RCS Support Engineer - Rio de Janeiro

completion:
BR
Guanglin
 
From:
 SI, Guanglin 
Sent:
 Wednesday, May 28, 2025 10:17 AM
To:
 Team RCS Singapore <team.RCSSingapore@marlink.com>
Subject:
 Product Updates - May
 
Hi,
 
As we got lowest score about ABC strategy on voice@marlink survey, I’ll try to summarize it on a high level: 
 
We at Marlink try to build a platform that is independent from any operators, E.g., Starlink, Inmarsat and etc., so that we can provide our own solution and also stay in control of it
“Product” is only part of it, and many customers don’t have the resource to manage the complex system, especially with IT/OT involved, so we also need to provide “service”
 
So, in the effort to archive that, we are lunching below:
Starlink SNG SCAP, so that we are not limited by the Starlink offerings, e.g. 1TB and etc.
Inmarsat GX – wave service: basically, we treat Inmarsat the same as Intelsat and get nothing but only the satellite bandwidth from them. No FBB, No NSD, No VAS including voice. Thanks to that, we will have SNG Ka offering, just like the existing SNG (Ku) plan
“Professional services”: we will manage Xchange, vessel LAN, on customer’s behalf
“Service management” : SM will provide consultancy service, e.g., periodic review, reporting and etc
 
You can find the details in the recording, or feel free to raise questions about it next Wednesday.
 
 
 
 
 
BR
Guanglin

prompt:
Write a professional email response regarding the following topic:
Subject: No subject
Context: ...
completion:
Hi,
 
As we got lowest score about ABC strategy on voice@marlink survey, I’ll try to summarize it on a high level: 
 
We at Marlink try to build a platform that is independent from any operators, E.g., Starlink, Inmarsat and etc., so that we can provide our own solution and also stay in control of it
“Product” is only part of it, and many customers don’t have the resource to manage the complex system, especially with IT/OT involved, so we also need to provide “service”
 
So, in the effort to archive that, we are lunching below:
 Starlink SNG SCAP, so that we are not limited by the Starlink offerings, e.g. 1TB and etc.
Inmarsat GX – wave service: basically, we treat Inmarsat the same as Intelsat and get nothing but only the satellite bandwidth from them. No FBB, No NSD, No VAS including voice. Thanks to that, we will have SNG Ka offering, just like the existing SNG (Ku) plan
 “Professional services”: we will manage Xchange, vessel LAN, on customer’s behalf
“Service management” : SM will provide consultancy service, e.g., periodic review, reporting and etc
 
You can find the details in the recording, or feel free to raise questions about it next Wednesday.
 
 
 
 
 
BR
Guanglin

Subject:
 SLA Dashboards
 
Hi Team,
Below are the two dashboards. Please keep an eye on them to monitor the report accuracy.
TTO  
Dashboard link
TTU  
Dashboard link
All timestamps are in UTC.
TTO:
This updates at 12 AM every day, and consists of two parts:
A table listing all RCS tickets that violated TTO in the past 24 hours
Default TTO is 120 mins,  except 60 mins on CMA and 30 mins on Boskalis. 
Hourly average TTO trend across the last 24 hours
 
This dashboard only monitors tickets created by RCS.
 
Data on 9
th
 May, captured yesterday:
 
Note:
Time reference is based on the email received timestamp (InDateTime)
Timestamps are rounded down to the hour (e.g., 01:59 AM is grouped under 1 AM). This setting can be adjusted later if needed.
Full ticket list can be found on 
Detailed ticket table
, for cross checking.
 
 
TTU 
This report captures TTU every 4 hrs, 6 times a day, and it only checks on “in progress” & unassigned RCS tickets.
Column charts show the longest delay since 
the last ticket action
. 
E.g., at 12 AM UTC 10
th
 May, ticket 1782530 had the longest delay, of 16.2 hrs
Similarly, 4 hrs later, at 4 AM, out of all RCS tickets, ticket 1760491 had the longest delay, of 4.3 hrs 
The 3 delayed tickets are displayed underneath the chart, for cross checking
This dashboard is a collection of 6 induvial reports, each refreshing at different hours, as indicated by “Snapshothour”. 
 E.g., the 3
st
 one, Snapshot 8 means that report updates at 8 AM daily. So, if I check that at 4AM here, then I’m still seeing yesterday’s data, so 0.9 was what we left with 
yesterday
. But if Rasto checks that at 10AM, then that report should have already updated, so it will show what they start with 
today
 
This is the same logic that Merits dashboard uses. E.g., at 12 AM, 1782530 was on the top of our dashboard:
 
Limitations:  
Due to some licensing constraints, TTU dashboard only records the data for last 24 hrs, and we can’t backtrace further or adjust the time frame easily. 
It’s known that above logic may underestimate TTU, since it only checks the last action, not the last customer incoming email. I have made another dashboard based on ticket Changelog  
Dashboard link
, which calculates how long the ticket has been in “In Progress” status, but for now, I suggest use the one above for consistency , as it aligns with how Merits works
 
@TSOTRAS, Antonios
 Your teams are not yet included in these dashboards, as they are under a different Merits Resource ID. If helpful, I can add your team in, or you can refer to my Wednesday email and set up your own version. I’m sure you’ll enjoy that.
Thanks.
BR
Guanglin

Subject:
 INMARSAT SAFETYLINK MIGRATION - LETTER TO DIRECT CUSTOMERS
 
Dear Support Team,
We are planning to  send the letter below) to all our Inm-C 
Direct 
Customers by  email tomorrow 
(29/05/2025)
:
This letter will be sent from the 
price.notification@marlink.com
 address to all known customer’s email addresses,
In this letter, we inform all our direct Inm-C customers that we will migrate their terminal to the new Safety Link provisioning tool starting after the 
20th of June, 2025
 ,
If customer does not agree to this migration, we ask them to contact us back via a 
“Contact us” button
 embedded in the email 
(
it will not be
 
 possible to reply to the email sent
),
Contact us button is routed to 
ServiceDesk@marlink.com
,
If a customer contacts Service Desk, we kindly ask RCS to create a  ticket and move it to 
MSS back office
 resource (Kelly’s team).
 
Can you please make sure that your teams are aware and ready to take actions?
Thanks a lot for your support,
Frdric Servat
 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dear Marlink Customer,
 
We hope this message finds you well. 
As part of our continuous commitment to providing the best services and enhanced safety at sea, we have started the migration of all  the Inmarsat-C terminals  registered with Marlink to the new SafetyLink self-service portal since 1
st
 of May,2025 
 
Inmarsat announced the first introduction of this new provisioning tool in July 2024. Since then, we have worked on upgrading our administration tools  and we are now ready to proceed with this migration as per Inmarsat’s recommendations. 
 
We want to remind you that: 
SafetyLink will connect to the ITU Maritime Mobile Access and Retrieval System (MARS) website so radio licensing can be checked by all stakeholders in real time, helping to ensure the validity of the terminal’s registration. 
The vessel owner will be invoiced by Marlink, as their Preferred Land Earth Station Operator (PLESO). 
F
or most of the countries, it will 
no longer be necessary to use a Point of Service Activation (PSA) entity to activate or change any details of the activation. 
Once moved to the SafetyLink portal, your Inm-C terminals will only
 
be able to connect to the Preferred LESO stations, being Marlink Land Earth Station in Aussaguel (LES id21) or Eik (LES id04). This migration will protect Inm-C terminal owners from higher roaming costs. 
Note that the working of the GMDSS distress signal is not impacted by this change.  
 
What if you do not agree with the migration:
If you do not agree that your Inm-C terminals are migrated to SafetyLink, you shall notify Marlink by 
Friday 20
th
 of June 2025
 at the latest. Marlink will not migrate your terminal from ESAS (Inmarsat legacy system) and you will risk higher roaming costs. 
Besides, if your terminal does not migrate to SafetyLink, an additional Inmarsat charge shall then apply at 
ten dollars ($10)
 per terminal per month from 
1
st
 of July 2025
.
This letter shall serve as a price increase notification per Marlink General Terms and Conditions in case you withhold your consent. 
 
 
 
 
What to Expect
Our team is committed to making the transition as seamless as possible. Over the coming weeks, you can reach out to our Inmarsat-C expert team  to get guidance from our  support team throughout the process.
 
How to Prepare
To ensure a smooth transition, we recommend that you:
Review your current Inmarsat-C terminal setup and more specifically that you make sure that your Inmarsat-C terminal uses one of the two Marlink Inmarsat-C Land Earth Station : 
Aussaguel (LES id21) or Eik (LES id04). 
Keep your contact details up to date with our customer service team so that you receive timely updates and assistance.
 
Need Help?
We understand that transitions can sometimes be challenging, and we are here to support you every step of the way. If you have any questions or require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact our dedicated support team at 
servicesdesk@marlink.com
 .
Thank you for your continued trust in Marlink. We look forward to supporting you through this transition and beyond.
 
 
-----------------------------------------------------
Frdric Servat
Senior Product Manager 
M +33 (0)6 31 64 60 97
E  
frederic.servat@marlink.com
www.marlink.com

that CCTS should not return the case back to RCS,
 asking for customer PO confirmation, clarification on setup and etc. They shall reach out to customer/KAM/CSE by themselves. 
 
Our job in RCS is:
 
For fleet change:
Informs the customer the change will be charged (script screenshot below), adds the KAM in copy of the ticket (for information) and asks the customer if he would like to proceed with the request. Note: the request should be from office, not vessel. 
Once the customer confirms to proceed and/
or ask for a quote
, assign the ticket to CCTS. (CCTS to advise on how long the job will take for the quotation)
 
For change on specific vessel:
 
Informs the customer the change will be charged (script below), adds the KAM in copy of the ticket (for information) and asks the customer if he would like to proceed with the request. Note: the request should be from office, not vessel. 
If customer asks for quotation, refer him to KAM. Once the customer confirms to proceed:
WAN/LAN changes: pass to MNOC Brat
Other changes: RCS makes the changes and logs the change in NetworkChangeLog in Merits
 
Be reminded that the “other changes” only consist of below items. E.g., “adding a crew account” is not included. 
 
Let me know if you have any questions. 
 
 
BR

Hi Eirik, 
 
Good morning.  I’ve discussed with Pierre on the tasks required. As spoken for UTM deployment, it is mainly remotely configured and loaded.  Pierre and his team usually does the pre/ deployment which consists of the following tasks:
 
FortiGate Environment  
1.1  FortiGate  
1.2  FortiManager  
1.3  FortiAnalyzer  
Pre-Deployment
  
2.1  Incoming Installation and Sharepoint  
2.1.1  Merits  
2.1.2  Sharepoint  
2.2  Prerequisites: Check XChange Box Configuration  
2.2.1  XChange Box features  
2.2.2  Cloud configuration  
2.2.3  Access  
2.3  XChange Cloud Subscription  
2.4  XChange Backdoor Configuration
 
2.5  Preconfigure the FortiGate device on the FortiManager 
2.5.1 Add the FortiGate device on the FortiManager  
2.6  Configure the XChange Box  
2.6.1 By using the XChange Box WebUI via URA  
2.7  Cloud Synchronization acceleration 
 
2.8  Vessel Deployment Sheet  
 
Deployment  
3.1  Push the network template  
3.2  After deployment check list and connectivity tests 
 
3.3  Merits update  
3.3.1 Deployment ticket  
3.3.2 Edit Installation 
 
 
 
Then, we will need to look at 2 types of support requests from the customers. 
 
Issues after remote deployment of the UTM 
 
Support after vessel is live after UTM deployment 
The level 2 / future support for this role will need access to the following:
access to the back-office
access to URA
access to FMG/FAZ
 
with the above, the support colleague will pretty much be able to manage the above – with exception of adding new users in the Fortigate but we have discussed and feel this is not an urgent support case during Asia Time Zone. Adding of users can be done later by the global team. 
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and if we should setup a follow up call on this to progress the topic further. 
 
Eastern Pacific is on their 2
nd
 POC vessel and Is still concern with the support they will receive if they go commercial. But as mentioned, the support will not just be for EPS but for ONE, OneSea, and many more. Thanks.

Hi Franck / Luc,
 
For your preparation, I’d like to understand the below during our meeting. Talk to you soon.
 
2 types of support involved:
- Deployment
- Post-deployment
 
Deployment:
- How many hours does it take to deploy 1 vessel?
- How do CCTS and network delivery interact on this?
 
Post-deployment:
- What are the common issues? How urgent are they?
- Possible to estimate how frequent a vessel encounters UTM issue? Or, how many UTM cases does CCTS get per week or month?
 
Training:
- Any documents, e.g., about deployment, activation and etc
- I presume session from Hans will be about deployment. If so, is it necessary to arrange separate ones for post-deployment cases?
- As informed by KAM, 4 deployments are planned in June, any chance for on-job training?
 
Operation:
- Any additional access that we shall get, on top of backoffice and URA? Our access to fortigate is read-only
- If it's beyond RCS capacity, will there be an 24x7 escalation point? I understand that CCTS on-duty phone is not for this purpose 
- Is it required to define a demarcation line?
 
BR

 SNG MSS standby Process v1.2 20250110.xlsx
 
Hi 
As the alerting of “all SNG barriers are down” now is active for all custome
rs I am sharing the latest SNG cold backup activation procedure attached.
 
Please share with Your teams so they can familiarize themselves with the details in the MSS standby process.
RCS tasks in short:
Receive alert mail and create ticket 
Troubleshoot connectivity
If unsuccessful troubleshooting, create 2 sub tickets to MSS BO: One for SIM activation and one for evaluating if the customer should be shared for the activation.
When resolved notification is received created sub ticket to MSS BO for deactivation of SIM. 
 
The following alert mails are sent to 
servicedesk@marlink.com
 in case of outage:
 
After 1 hour down FIREING notification will come,
There is a RESOLVED notification sent right after the issue is confirmed resolved. (
The criteria is for one bearer to be online again -+9 min because it checks status every 10min). 
 
Some more info:

 UTM Support

2 types of support involved:

- Post-deployment

BR
Guanglin

Subject:
 INMARSAT SAFETYLINK MIGRATION - LETTER TO DIRECT CUSTOMERS
 
Dear Support Team,
We are planning to  send the letter below) to all our Inm-C 
Direct 
Customers by  email tomorrow 
(29/05/2025)
:
This letter will be sent from the 
price.notification@marlink.com
 address to all known customer’s email addresses,
In this letter, we inform all our direct Inm-C customers that we will migrate their terminal to the new Safety Link provisioning tool starting after the 
20th of June, 2025
 ,
If customer does not agree to this migration, we ask them to contact us back via a 
“Contact us” button
 embedded in the email 
(
it will not be
 
 possible to reply to the email sent
),
Contact us button is routed to 
ServiceDesk@marlink.com
,
If a customer contacts Service Desk, we kindly ask RCS to create a  ticket and move it to 
MSS back office
 resource (Kelly’s team).
 
Can you please make sure that your teams are aware and ready to take actions?
Thanks a lot for your support,
Frdric Servat
 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dear Marlink Customer,
 
We hope this message finds you well. 
As part of our continuous commitment to providing the best services and enhanced safety at sea, we have started the migration of all  the Inmarsat-C terminals  registered with Marlink to the new SafetyLink self-service portal since 1
st
 of May,2025 
 
Inmarsat announced the first introduction of this new provisioning tool in July 2024. Since then, we have worked on upgrading our administration tools  and we are now ready to proceed with this migration as per Inmarsat’s recommendations. 
 
We want to remind you that: 
SafetyLink will connect to the ITU Maritime Mobile Access and Retrieval System (MARS) website so radio licensing can be checked by all stakeholders in real time, helping to ensure the validity of the terminal’s registration. 
The vessel owner will be invoiced by Marlink, as their Preferred Land Earth Station Operator (PLESO). 
F
or most of the countries, it will 
no longer be necessary to use a Point of Service Activation (PSA) entity to activate or change any details of the activation. 
Once moved to the SafetyLink portal, your Inm-C terminals will only
 
be able to connect to the Preferred LESO stations, being Marlink Land Earth Station in Aussaguel (LES id21) or Eik (LES id04). This migration will protect Inm-C terminal owners from higher roaming costs. 
Note that the working of the GMDSS distress signal is not impacted by this change.  
 
What if you do not agree with the migration:
If you do not agree that your Inm-C terminals are migrated to SafetyLink, you shall notify Marlink by 
Friday 20
th
 of June 2025
 at the latest. Marlink will not migrate your terminal from ESAS (Inmarsat legacy system) and you will risk higher roaming costs. 
Besides, if your terminal does not migrate to SafetyLink, an additional Inmarsat charge shall then apply at 
ten dollars ($10)
 per terminal per month from 
1
st
 of July 2025
.
This letter shall serve as a price increase notification per Marlink General Terms and Conditions in case you withhold your consent. 
 
 
 
 
What to Expect
Our team is committed to making the transition as seamless as possible. Over the coming weeks, you can reach out to our Inmarsat-C expert team  to get guidance from our  support team throughout the process.
 
How to Prepare
To ensure a smooth transition, we recommend that you:
Review your current Inmarsat-C terminal setup and more specifically that you make sure that your Inmarsat-C terminal uses one of the two Marlink Inmarsat-C Land Earth Station : 
Aussaguel (LES id21) or Eik (LES id04). 
Keep your contact details up to date with our customer service team so that you receive timely updates and assistance.
 
Need Help?
We understand that transitions can sometimes be challenging, and we are here to support you every step of the way. If you have any questions or require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact our dedicated support team at 
servicesdesk@marlink.com
 .
Thank you for your continued trust in Marlink. We look forward to supporting you through this transition and beyond.
 
 
-----------------------------------------------------
Frdric Servat
Senior Product Manager 
M +33 (0)6 31 64 60 97
E  
frederic.servat@marlink.com
www.marlink.com
